subsections.title: Greek and Egyptian Rituals
subsections.content: The construction was within the sacred precinct of the god. It should also be noted that the rites of Dionysus so closely resembled those of the Egyptian god Osiris that Herodotus thought it impossible for the Greek rites to have risen independently of the Egyptian ones. He therefore supposed that the Greeks must have borrowed their rites from the Egyptians and, with slight alterations, passed them on as their own. Plutarch also insisted upon the detailed resemblances between the rites of Osiris and those of Dionysus, indicating that comparative mythology is not merely a modern tool as some critics have maintained. In this case, no borrowing need be called for; what is fundamentally present is that whatever Dionysus originally stood for was essentially the same as what Osiris originally represented. In simpler terms, Osiris and Dionysus are representations of the same original phenomenon—simply different national guises of the same god. Others have maintained that the similarity of Greek rituals to those of the Egyptians stems from the Greeks' ignorance of Egyptian practices. Thus, for instance, Gwyn Griffiths argued that Greek observers were 'not usually in a position' to understand Egyptian religion, particularly because of their ignorance of the Egyptian language.

bibliography: 1. W. Oates & E. O’Neil, The Complete Greek Drama (1938), p. xxiii.
2. J. G. Frazer, The Golden Bough (London, 1974, abridged edition), p. 507.
4. G. J. Griffiths, 'Interpretatio Graeca,' in W. Helck & E. Otto, Lexikon der Agyptologie, Vol. II (1980), col. 167.

subsections.title: Performance of Oedipus Rex
subsections.content: Performance of Oedipus Rex in the theater of Dionysus on the south slope of the Acropolis of Athens. Actors wore masks, each playing more than one role.

subsections.title: Altar of Dionysus
subsections.content: Note the altar of Dionysus in the center of the orchestra. (Illustration(s) by John Green.)

subsections.title: Roman Theater
subsections.content: Actors performing in a Roman Theater. Although it has been stated that Roman drama was a secular diversion with its roots in sacred Etruscan funeral rites, it was actually nothing more than a Greek derivative of Hellenic repertory. (Illustration by John Green.)

subsections.title: Egyptian Religion
subsections.content: Misunderstandings of Egyptian phenomena were compounded by modifications introduced by what the Greeks saw as parallels. According to Griffiths, each deviation caused by misunderstanding, whether radical or slight, would have contributed to one more 'remove' from the original version. Ancient Egyptian religion, often denigrated, was respected and understood by individuals such as Eudoxos, who lived with priests and studied Egyptian, fostering a great respect for their culture. Despite criticism of Bernal from mainstream scholars, his assertion that modern mythologists believe they understand the ancients better than the ancients themselves may still hold truth. The main point is not whether tragedy was originally concerned with Dionysiac ritual but whether it truly originated as a direct response to it. Historical reflection suggests that Greek opinion converged on the point that tragedy, derived from the Greek word 'tragodia,' or 'goat song,' evokes the violent death of a god, particularly in its homage to Dionysus.

bibliography: 3. M. Bernal, Black Athena (New Brunswick, 1988), p. 118.
6. R. M. Dorson, 'The Debate Over the Trustworthiness of Oral Traditional History,' cited by D. B. Vitaliano, Legends of the Earth (Bloomington, 1973), p. 4.

subsections.title: Oral Tradition
subsections.content: Oral tradition in sub-Saharan Africa demonstrated the ability to preserve history without a written language up until colonial times. Peter Hallberg's observations regarding Icelandic skalds indicate that history transmitted through a succession of professional bards retains accuracy over generations. Alfred de Grazia noted the potential for trained speakers to memorize extensive works such as Homer's epics over time. The retention and recall of epic narratives, demonstrated through systematic learning methods characteristic of childhood education, confirm the power of oral tradition. Though the hexameter form of Homer's poetry may have roots in oral traditions that aid memorability, it is essential to understand its broader implications on the integrity of oral narratives.

bibliography: 5. C. Sagan & I. S. Shklovskii, Intelligent Life in the Universe (N. Y., 1966), p. 464.

subsections.title: Scandinavian Skald
subsections.content: A Scandinavian skald, or bard, reciting a saga from memory to a chieftain and his tribe.

subsections.title: Heroes of the Trojan War
subsections.content: Heroes of the Trojan War. From left to right: Menelaus, Paris, Diomedes, Odysseus, Nestor, Achilles, Agamemnon. An artist’s impression.

subsections.title: Gudrun Epic
subsections.content: Recent explorations into the Gudrun Epic have revealed its historical basis and geographical integrity. Hildegard Wiencke-Lotz traveled extensively to validate the epic's connection to various locations, demonstrating that the tales are rooted in indigenous traditions. This was affirmed through archaeological discoveries throughout Europe, revealing accurate historical narratives across regions connected by the Goths. The fidelity of oral traditions illustrates their ability to maintain accuracy despite the passage of centuries, achieving a remarkable level of preservation in cultural memory.

bibliography: 1. D. Griffard, from the 'Introductory Notes' to H. Wiencke-Lotz, 'Folklore: Its Stability and Self-correcting Power,' HORUS II:2 (Summer 1986), p. 29.

subsections.title: Writing on Papyrus
subsections.content: Making and writing on papyrus. In Egypt, literacy was limited; scribes played a crucial role in society. The word 'paper' derives from the Greek for papyrus, which was made from pressed stalks. Despite its advantages, writing diminished the necessity of memorizing the past. Thoth, the Egyptian god of letters, is critiqued for introducing writing as it favored forgetfulness over the practice of memory. When the Egyptians later read texts from their ancestors, they sometimes struggled to comprehend them due to a lack of firsthand experience.

bibliography: 1. Plato, Phaedrus, as translated by H. N. Fowler, 274-275 (emphasis added).
